Belgia 1594 July 10.
S
r
Thomas Bodley his letter to the Lord Burley the 10 July
1594
./
Maye it please yo
r
good Lordshipe I have nothing more
to signefy for myne owne Negotiation till I heare from yo
r
Lordshipe, It might have steeded me muche for manye
respect
if untylle that hir
Ma
ty
had fully Resolved, I
myghte ether have knowne by some lytle intymacone
wheareuppon it hath Stayed, or had somwhat sayde
unto me, to interteyne then heare the whill, for altho-
ughe I have devised the beste that I Could, to Aunswere
their demaund
yet I see they are Not satysfyed, and
I am alwayes uncertene howe well my Aunsweres
maye accorde w
th
hir Ma
t
designes. It is signefy-
ed very Nowe by letters from the Campe, that the first
of this Monthe of the Ravelin, wheare our souldyeres had
mynd
Myned and placed store of poudere, was sette a
fyre and blowne upp, w
th
200 men in it, of w
ch
ther
weare very fewe saved, but weare ether by the myne
or by our Men after slayne, and many of them drow-
ned in the watere faste by, The Ravelin theareuppon
was presently assayled, and taken by the Scott
, whos
quartere was Neareste, w
ch
is thoughte a great stepe
to the takyng of the towne, and we hope in lyke ma-
nnere to heare every howere of some spessyall attempte
to be gevene besyd
/ for our approches Ghalleryes other
mynes and work
are brought so neeare unto the Ra-
mpires in 5 or 6 places, as they weare Redy it is tho-
ughte about 4 dayes plaste, to geve uppon the
Toune
in all thos places at an instante, as in the meane
tyme havinge planted their Artyllery uppon 9 or 10
bedes in severall places that shoote daye and Nighthe
and kylle very many./
Count Mauris
in goinge a
bout to visset the work
, was defended from a bullete
by the meanes of his Targett, of w
ch
a splyntere brak
out and hurte his page standinge by, The wether here
for this Monthe hathe byne Exceedinge wette & windy
w
ch
hathe byne agreate hindrance to the Advauntage of
of our work
it is thought that otherwise, before this
wee mighte have Caryed the Towne, this benefite
wee have onlye that the Marrishes thearby are waxed
very deepe, So as the Enemyes hathe No meanes to
Convaye in any Souldyeres w
ch
he did oftentymes be-
fore / Theare is a speeche that 400 of
Verdugos
souldiers are Mutenyed and have lefte him,
Erne-
stus
wee heare dothe assemble all his forces for some
spesyall purpos w
ch
is unknowne yet heare, bute
onely by Conjecture having sente alredy to the Castell
of
Wo
adjoyninge to
Bergene
300 mariners it is
supposed he intend
uppon the Ile of
Tertoll,
it is Ad-
vertysed hether from the Enemyes Contrey that the Co-
Countye
fol.213v
Counte Charles Mansffeelde
is gone to the Spawe
leavinge moste of his troupes betweene
Arras
&
Dowas
Douay
/ The Brute goethe heare that the
Prince of An-
holte
is Come to Counte Mauris as they saye but to see
and salute him but by Resone of a secrete motyone, w
ch
hathe byne made by frend
hearetofore for a matche
betweene the Prince and the
Lady
Emilia de Nassau
Counte Mauris sistere bothe by
Father
and
mothere,
it
is supposed that his Comynge is Cheefly for that, but
for oughte I Cane
ceave by talke w
th
thos that seem
to knowe it the Ladye hathe noe fancye to marye w
th
any Germaine / Theare are appoynted from hence
to goe in to Scotland to the Baptysynge of the Prince
Mounser
Brederode
the Eldere and
Mounser Valke
of
Zeelande
for that yo
r
Lordshipe maye desyre to see a plot
of this seege I endevored longe agoe to sette on a worke
but it was Not possyble w
th
any safty to the workeman
to doe it w
th
any
fectnes tylle our Artyllery was
thorowely planted, nowe the inclosed is sente unto
me w
ch
is done somwhat sleightely and in a smalle
Ro
o
me w
th
out any Trimynge for that the
ty dothe
mis
to send me alargere and exactere, howbeit he dothe
assure me that the Juste distance betweene oure Campe
and the towne, the Compas the entrenchemente & the
Lenghte of the towne w
th
the forme of the Angles port
and bulwark
togeher w
th
the foart
, wateres, wayes
and suche other general thing
in that soarte as they
presente them selves toward
our Campe, are set
doune in juste proporsyone accordinge to the scall
of Paces joyned to it, w
ch
is onely mente of orde-
nary goinge paces, accountyn g two foote to a pace
Althoughe it be Noe draughte to Contente yo
r
lor-
dshipe yet for that it is the first that I have yet
seene and is done by a skylfull
sone who sente
it me hether in a Ruder forme I have Caused it
heare to be somewhat better drawne, and I send it
hearewithe /
And thus for this present I take my
humble Leave, from the Hage. July 10
1594.
Yo
r
Lordships [most] humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
